items.title: Keep Calm and Carry On
items.creator: Ministry of Information
items.summary: Originally produced by the British government in 1939 in preparation for World War II, 'Keep Calm and Carry On' was intended to raise public morale in the event of invasion. Its simple, bold design and reassuring message remain iconic.

items.title: We Can Do It!
items.creator: J. Howard Miller
items.summary: Created for Westinghouse Electric as an inspirational image to boost worker morale, the 'We Can Do It!' poster features Rosie the Riveter, a symbol of female empowerment and America's can-do approach to the war effort during World War II.

items.title: I Want You for U.S. Army
items.creator: James Montgomery Flagg
items.summary: One of the most iconic recruiting posters of World War I, featuring Uncle Sam pointing directly at the viewer with the words 'I Want You for U.S. Army', aimed at encouraging American men to enlist in the army.

items.title: This Is the Enemy
items.creator: Office of War Information
items.summary: A World War II propaganda poster depicting the enemy in a dehumanizing manner to instill a sense of urgency and danger, often used to galvanize public support for the war effort against Axis powers.

items.title: Loose Lips Might Sink Ships
items.creator: Office of War Information
items.summary: An American World War II propaganda poster that was part of a broader campaign to prevent espionage and sabotage. It encouraged discretion and caution in communication to avoid inadvertently providing useful information to enemy spies.
